The council was scheduled to discuss the U.N. North Korea sanctions resolution that the US & China jointly drafted on Thursday at 3 p.m. ET (2000 GMT), but I read elsewhere that there may be a special meeting on Saturday.  A Russian source said that they needed time, and it would be next week before they'd be ready to vote on it.

26 Feb: No turning back for China after 2mths negotiations, proposal in days. Legislation circulated Thu (NYT: http://nyti.ms/1KNN37i). Only thing at this point to deter is DPRK violent reaction. 75%-->99%
25 Feb: US-China agree on resolution but Beijing still prefers negotiation table (WSJ: http://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-china-agree-to-sanction-north-korea-on-nuclear-program-1456383545) 25%-->75%. Key q: How often has China backed out of supporting draft resolution at last minute?
Going up until it's clear if the proposed sanctions will be accepted by all members of the Security Council.

Surely the only thing that can stop this is Russia holding out for a deal in return for their support. But they are seeking to be a major ally of China now and it is hard to see how they could hold a line for long which would risk total isolation from both East and west - not their strategy.  The probability of failure for me is simply procedural delay.

China is terrified of a collapse of NK because of the tidal wave of refugees it would unleash. That's why they have continued to have been been allies of sorts despite all that weirdness. The Chinese government has been encouraging citizens along the border to form militias, a scary thing for the government to do, suggesting desperation. Also, China has built a bridge to nowhere across the Yalu river bordering the two nations, quite substantial. https://www.nknews.org/2014/10/new-yalu-river-bridge-opening-postponed/
This question seems like a lock in the affirmative.

Obama is going to push for this as much as possible as there is no downside. He can see another foreign policy success before the election.

UN security council resolutions are frequent
BUT has only adopted 4 resolutions that impose sanctions on North Korea since 2006
The first two resolutions were passed shortly after North Korean nuclear tests in 2006 and 2009. The third came a month after North Korea successfully launched a satellite in December 2012
North Korea supposedly tested a hydrogen bomb
All major powers, particularly China and Russia have called for further resolutions
they are afraid that china will be upset

(no change) Considering that China may be more inclined to support something with news that some factions in South Korea would like to re-start their nuclear weapons effort.

China may not agree. They claim that more sanctions would be punitive, rather than a deterrent and would lead to destabilization.

The US & Japan have already announced sanctions; S Korea has taken some action as well - China is still holding out & calling for calm & for parties to get together which appears unlikely at the moment. What happens as we get closer to the May meeting in NK will determine if the UNSC can consense. If NK provokes again (likely given its internal compulsions) then the chances of sanctions increase significantly; if they appear to soften, chances recede.
The US already has announced new sanctions, even though they are pretty slim, only attacking those who help the nuclear effort on NK, which doesn't seem much.

I'm not sure whether the decision by US and South Korea to deploy a THAAD system in South Korea will help or hinder getting the Chinese on board for sanctions. But, at this point, it looks like China will agree to some sanctions, even if they don't hit the North Korean economy as hard as the US would like.
The PRC and the US are not as chummy on this issue as they were last time.  Still, Beijing could decide to sit on its hands when the vote comes up.  An abstention is not a veto.

I am convinced yes, but what does it mean at the end? nothing !   On North Korea the entire world is completely cloutless wha to do, since this country's regime seems totally impermeable to anything from outside.
leaving a smidge for the bureaucracy of time...

While new NK santions are likely, they will almost certainly be piecemeal, decided by each country (or region). A large number of geopolitical crisises will continue to distract the Security Council from North Korea's saber rattling and nuclear tests. It's hard to care about smoke coming out of your neighbors house, when your own is on fire... ISIS, Russian Aggression, Chinese Expansion, the US Political Election cycle, and the global financial slowdown will continue to dominate attentions, leaving scant left for NK.

While the United States and its partners would support this, and even China might feel like it is justified, great power politics will trump the issue. Russia is still not in a mood to work with the West. China has an aversion to many aspects of sanctions and will be wary of impacting its influence on Pyongyang. However if the North persists in confrontational activities (including recent slights to China) or if the big powers are in a more conciliatory mood, a resolution might past.

China will veto any resolution that includes substantive sanctions. They have a significant and legitimate fear of a refugee crisis should any substantive combinations of sanctions lead to a collapse of North Korea. As was mentioned in the first NYT piece: "China would rather live with a friendly North Korea with nukes than a non-friendly North Korea with nukes."
They should but it's moot!  North Korea is already cut off from the rest of the world. China is the one who should be sanctioned for enabling North Korea
China will veto any further sanctions for the time being, as a way to punish America for support free rights of passage in the South China Sea.
A meaningless resolution will pass to mollify those in the West.  China will make sure the resolution has no teeth.
N Korea is threathening its noughbours and  the US alltogether and is more and more becomming a threat for world peace
It could be scuttled by a debate between the US and China, but that doesn't seem very likely.
Continued Nuclear Weapons Launches need be answered.

Tough question:  China and Russia hold veto power in the UNSC;  whether it will allow other SC members succeed in having the resolution passed is till open to discussion.   China's vote will be decisive in the voting round.  There is no question that there will be a resolution presented to the UNSC, but is passage is still questionable.
dialing back.  Think THAAD deployment is freaking out Beijing and Beijing hawks.
With their military expansion, the sanctions will be necessary to contain the problem.

NYT Feb 7 article (link attached to question) explores the issue well & from all sides - China still wants to come across as a protector even though its diplomatic overtures have been rebuffed. So the balancing act continues while the rest of the UNSC will go along. Given its concerns on THAAD deployment in S Korea, it may be willing to agree to "minimum" measures that have symbolic value. So this could happen within the next 2-3 weeks else the probabilities in this case will start going down with passage of time.
They may disagree, but a token sanction will not hurt China's position.

UNSC imposed/expanded sanctions every time North Korea detonated its nuclear devices. It may take some time to determine details, but USNC is highly likely to expand sanctions on NK before 1 June 2016.
Sanctions will pass, though watered down enough to get China's approval
Up 3% to be above consensus. While unlikely to have any real effect on the DPRK, sanctions will show that the system is "working" and are relatively low consequence.
think everyone, even RU and CN, can agree that NK has gone off the deep end.

With the recent US Senate vote to increase sanctions, there should be a push from the US to get sanctions via the UN. China will be the sticking point. The internal unrest in nK has China concerned. The last thing the Chinese want is for Kim Jong Un's regime to fail and nK to collapse (coup/revolution etc) sending a stream of refugees into China.  But, then people have been predicting nK's (& the Kim family) "imminent" fall for decades.

Upgrading it slightly due to recent missile launch. Previously, a successful missile launch was cause for UN sanctions. However, most recently, the nuclear test on Jan. 16 did not result in additional sanctions, leading me to believe that this will also not result in sanctions. China has strong reasons not to approve additional sanctions on North Korea. Mainly because a failed North Korean state will have the biggest impact on China, and relations are already not good--for example, the North Korean girl pop band that left Beijing without performing.
It looks like this one might be resolved quite quickly.
It seems like the sensible thing for the UN to do but with so many other goals and tensions between the members that I don't have a lot of certainty.
US owns the Security Council take 1% off for Russia or China veto
Dialing it up +3. This has got to be another "egg on its way to the floor" question. I started too low at 92%...
This is the kind of question that can close as "yes" on little notice, therefore starting high makes strategic sense.
Everybody is, I think, far too optimistic.
Wondering what kind of additional sanctions fit this case in such a timeframe, but sure, some sanctions will.

Before the ballistic missile test conducted by North Korea, I would have pegged this at only 25% or less - given the most recent minutes from the Security Council and its discussion of North Korea.  The ballistic missile test moved me further in the direction, but I'm hesitant to overreact.  Additionally, consensus seems to be defacto standard for the council, even though it is not required.  China and a few others are opposed to interfering, so the Council may have to land on having individual members impose their own sanctions.

As he often does, the Pyongyang Kid has thrown a bit of tantrum to show he's not China's puppet.  They will now need to show that they're not his puppet.  They'll buy at least some limited sanctions in aid of this objective.  He'll be blowing something up again soon, which will accelerate the process so that it meets the deadline for this Q.

China has little room to negotiate in this measure, enough pressure will make them accept or not vote. Their economy is not great and the recent pull out of S Korea from the industrial complex they have with N Korea is a financial loss on China. They are also expanding their trading with Japan and S Korea and do not want that new alliance to slow due to political tension in the area. They may use a sanction vote as a way to leverage an agreement with THAAD or other 'annoyances' that China has with the West.
Black Swan: The recent military purges and sanctions may weaken the central government to where N Korea may look for other ways to solve some of their own immediate issues with outside cooperation.

Up 10% to get right with the consensus. Agree with all the reasons there may be; agree that getting Russia and China to sign on is complicated. Pro: could even apply something targeted that is symbolic. Con: sanction fatigue. The history of sanctions being effective is mixed at best.
North Korea's provocations cannot be ignored, especially after this last launch that enlarges the radius of direct danger from NK.
In regards to Chinese interference, China aided the US in drafting UNSCR 2087 in 2013 after an underground nuclear test, and is frequently described as "annoyed" by NKs behavior.
High percentage. Everyone seems to be agreeing.
Xi is a different kind of cat  and I think China will offer token resistance then yield.
Even those opposed to sanctions will select them to prevent a missile defense system in South Korea.
Yes, but not targeting trade with China as US-SK-Japan would like
I wouldn't bother looking for priors. Chastising DPRK must be weekly business at the UN.

China: Unlikely to agree to sanctions (20%)
Russia: Unlikely to agree to sanctions, adversarial relationship with the West (25%)
US, France, UK: Likely to push for sanctions
Already heavy sanctions on NK, what else could be sanctioned?

Alright -- I know it's extreme, but given the current *heat* around this issue -- especially with news that NK is back into plutonium production! -- I'm gonna start at 100%. If nothing happens by the end of the month, then I'll back way off. A few things to think about:

The North Korean missile test isn't significant enough to provoke a UN response. They've tested missiles before, taken hostages and pulled all kinds of stunts. The UN has bigger problems right now, and further sanctions will only give NK the international attention that it craves. It's clear that sanctions aren't working, and the US and China will probably privately agree to another means of deterrent.

Although Russia and China will be impediments to much in the way of the expansion or the addition of effective sanctions, they would need to be much more cooperative in this endeavor if it eliminates, in turn, the placement of a THAAD unit in South Korea. Last thing either party wishes to see is a ABM system in the neighborhood with a proven ability to counter their offensive missile capabilities. Let's see if that becomes a bargaining chip...

My sense is the disagreement with China is over how severe to make the sanctions, not whether new sanctions will be imposed.  I also expect this will move quickly so I am starting high and can adjust down if nothing happens.
Yeah maybe the UN is kind of amorphous when it comes to action
The World will have to show that these type of moves Korea is doing will have stiff consequence. Even whatever move the UN does will not deter them..
North Korea's recent testing of missiles and weapons will drive a response

Based on previous actions and reactions by the UN Security council, there is almost a 100% chance the UN Security Council will pass a resolution before 1 June 2016. On average, a resolution has been adopted by the UN Security Council within 26.71 days after the event and the median days elapsed is 23 days. One standard deviation is equal to 17.58 days.
Resolutions and talk, yes; sanctions, perhaps not. Major issue to get Russia and China to approve something would probably be re-starting plutonium reactor.
They will remain weakened by China's reluctance, but believe China is increasingly unhappy with the recent NK events. U.S. likely to add sophisticated missile defense system in SK or Japan.
